speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Good afternoon.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I will begin with one overarching message: We at the Fed understand the hardship that high inflation is causing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are strongly committed to bringing inflation back down, and we’re moving expeditiously to do so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have both the tools we need and the resolve that it will take to restore price stability on behalf of American families and businesses.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The economy and the country have been through a lot over the past two and a half years and have proved resilient.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It is essential that we bring inflation down if we are to have a sustained period of strong labor market conditions that benefit all.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: From the standpoint of our congressional mandate to promote maximum employment and price stability, the current picture is plain to see: The labor market is extremely tight, and inflation is much too high.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Against this backdrop, today the Federal Open Market Committee raised its policy interest rate by ¾ percentage point and anticipates that ongoing increases in that rate will be appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In addition, we are continuing the process of significantly reducing the size of our balance sheet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’ll have more to say about today’s monetary policy actions after briefly reviewing economic developments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Overall economic activity edged down in the first quarter, as unusually sharp swings in inventories and net exports more than offset continued strong underlying demand.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Recent indicators suggest that real GDP growth has picked up this quarter, with consumption spending remaining strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In contrast, growth in business fixed investment appears to be slowing, and activity in the housing sector looks to be softening, in part reflecting higher mortgage rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The tightening in financial conditions that we’ve seen in recent months should continue to temper growth and help bring demand into better balance with supply.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As shown in our Summary of Economic Projections, FOMC participants have marked down their projections for economic activity, with the median projection for real GDP growth running below 2 percent through 2024.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The labor market has remained extremely tight, with the unemployment rate near a 50-year low, job vacancies at historical highs, and wage growth elevated.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over the past three months, employment rose by an average of 408,000 jobs per month, down from the average pace seen earlier in the year but still robust.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Improvements in labor market conditions have been widespread, including for workers at the lower end of the wage distribution as well as for African Americans and Hispanics.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Labor demand is very strong, while labor supply remains subdued, with the labor force participation rate little changed since January.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: FOMC participants expect supply and demand conditions in the labor market to come into better balance, easing the upward pressures on wages and prices.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The median projection in the SEP for the unemployment rate rises somewhat over the next few years, moving from 3.7 percent at the end of this year to 4.1 percent in 2024, levels that are noticeably above the March projections.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation remains well above our longer-run goal of 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over the 12 months ending in April, total PCE prices rose 6.3 percent; excluding the volatile food and energy categories, core prices rose 4.9 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In May, the 12-month change in the consumer price index came in above expectations at 8.6 percent, and the change in the core CPI was 6 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Aggregate demand is strong, supply constraints have been larger and longer lasting than anticipated, and price pressures have spread to a broad range of goods and services.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The surge in prices of crude oil and other commodities that resulted from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine is boosting prices for gasoline and food and is creating additional upward pressure on inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And COVID-related lockdowns in China are likely to exacerbate supply chain disruptions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: FOMC participants have revised up their projections for inflation this year, particularly for total PCE inflation given developments in food and energy prices.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The median projection is 5.2 percent this year and falls to 2.6 percent next year and 2.2 percent in 2024.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Participants continue to see risks to inflation as weighted to the upside.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Fed’s monetary policy actions are guided by our mandate to promote maximum employment and stable prices for the American people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: My colleagues and I are acutely aware that high inflation imposes significant hardship, especially on those least able to meet the higher costs of essentials like food, housing, and transportation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are highly attentive to the risks high inflation poses to both sides of our mandate, and we are strongly committed to returning inflation to our 2 percent objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Against the backdrop of the rapidly evolving economic environment, our policy has been adapting, and it will continue to do so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At today’s meeting, the Committee raised the target range for the federal funds rate by ¾ percentage point, resulting in a 1½ percentage point increase in the target range so far this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Committee reiterated that it anticipates that ongoing increases in the target range will be appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we are continuing the process of significantly reducing the size of our balance sheet—which plays an important role in firming the stance of monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Coming out of our last meeting in May, there was a broad sense on the Committee that a ½ percentage point increase in the target range should be considered at this meeting if economic and financial conditions evolved in line with expectations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We also stated that we were highly attentive to inflation risks and that we would be nimble in responding to incoming data and the evolving outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Since then, inflation has again surprised to the upside, some indicators of inflation expectations have risen, and projections for inflation this year have been revised up notably.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In response to these developments, the Committee decided that a larger increase in the target range was warranted at today’s meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This continues our approach of expeditiously moving our policy rate up to more normal levels.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it will help ensure that longer-term inflation expectations remain well anchored at 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As shown in the SEP, the median projection for the appropriate level of the federal funds rate is 3.4 percent at the end of this year, 1.5 percentage points higher than projected in March and 0.9 percentage point above the median estimate of its longer-run value.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The median projection rises further to 3.8 percent at the end of next year and declines to 3.4 percent in 2024, still above the median longer-run value.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, these projections do not represent a Committee plan or decision, and no one knows with any certainty where the economy will be a year or more from now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over coming months, we will be looking for compelling evidence that inflation is moving down, consistent with inflation returning to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We anticipate that ongoing rate increases will be appropriate; the pace of those changes will continue to depend on the incoming data and the evolving outlook for the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Clearly, today’s 75 basis point increase is an unusually large one, and I do not expect moves of this size to be common.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: From the perspective of today, either a 50 basis point or a 75 basis point increase seems most likely at our next meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will, however, make our decisions meeting by meeting, and we will continue to communicate our thinking as clearly as we can.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our overarching focus is using our tools to bring inflation back down to our 2 percent goal and to keep longer-term inflation expectations well anchored.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Making appropriate monetary policy in this uncertain environment requires a recognition that the economy often evolves in unexpected ways.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation has obviously surprised to the upside over the past year, and further surprises could be in store.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We therefore will need to be nimble in responding to incoming data and the evolving outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we will strive to avoid adding uncertainty in what is already an extraordinarily challenging and uncertain time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are highly attentive to inflation risks and determined to take the measures necessary to restore price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The American economy is very strong and well positioned to handle tighter monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: To conclude: We understand that our actions affect communities, families, and businesses across the country.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Everything we do is in service to our public mission.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We at the Fed will do everything we can to achieve our maximum-employment and price-stability goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I look forward to your questions.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Howard.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Howard Schneider with Reuters.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Two related questions.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Chair Powell, do you feel you boxed yourself in with the language you used at the last press conference on 50 basis point hikes in June and July?

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: And would you please give us as detailed a sense as you can of what role you played in reshaping market expectations so quickly on Monday?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, as you know, we always aim to provide as much clarity as we can about our policy intentions subject to the inherent uncertainty in the economic outlook, because we think monetary policy is more effective when market participants understand how policy will evolve, when they understand our objective function, our reaction function.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And in the current highly unusual circumstances with inflation well above our goal, we think it’s helpful to provide even more clarity than usual—again, subject to uncertainty in the outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think over the course of this year, financial markets have responded and have, generally, shown that they understand the path we’re laying out.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, it remains data dependent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so that’s what we generally think about guidance, and that’s why we offer it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, of course, when we offered that—when I offered that guidance at the last meeting, I did say that it was subject to the economy performing about in line with expectations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I also said that if the economy performed—if data came in worse than expected, then we would consider moving even more aggressively.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we got the CPI data and also some data on inflation expectations late last week, and we thought for a while, and we thought, well, this is the appropriate thing to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So then the question is, what do you do?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And do you wait six weeks to do it at the next meeting?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think the answer is, that’s not where we are with this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we decided we needed to go ahead, and so we did.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s really—that’s really how we made the decision.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Okay.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Jeanna.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: Thanks for taking our questions.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: Jeanna Smialek with the New York Times.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: You—I guess I wonder if you could describe for us a little bit how you’re deciding how aggressive you need to be.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: So, obviously, 75 today.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: What did 75 achieve that 50 wouldn’t have, and why not just go for a full percentage point at some point?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So if you take a step back, what we’re looking for is compelling evidence that inflationary pressures are abating and that inflation is moving back down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’d like to see that in the form of a series of declining monthly inflation readings—that’s what we’re looking for.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, by this point, we had actually been expecting to see clear signs of at least inflation flattening out and, ideally, beginning to decline.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve said that we’d be data dependent, focused on incoming data, highly attentive to inflation risks—the things that I mentioned to Howard moments ago.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So contrary to expectations, inflation again surprised to the upside.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Indicators—some indicators of inflation expectations have risen, and projections of [inflation] this year have moved up notably.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we thought that strong action was warranted at this meeting, and today we delivered that in the form of a 75 basis point rate hike, as I mentioned.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the point of it, really, is this: We’ve been moving rates up expeditiously to more normal levels, and over the course of the seven months since we pivoted and began moving in this direction, we’ve seen financial conditions tighten, and appropriately so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But the federal funds rate, even after this move, is at 1.6 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, again, the Committee is moving rates up expeditiously to more normal levels, and we came to the view that we’d like to do a little more front-end loading on that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think that the SEP gives you the levels that people think are appropriate at given points in time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This was really about the speed in which we would get there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, as I mentioned, 75 basis points today—I said the next meeting could well be about a decision between 50 and 75.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That would put us, at the end of the July meeting, in that range—in that more normal range, and that’s a desirable place to be, because you begin to have more optionality there about the speed with which you would proceed going forward.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Just talking about the SEP for a second: What it really says is that Committee participants widely would like to see policy at a modestly restricted—restrictive level at the end of this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s six months from now, and so much data [can accrue] and so much can happen, so remember how highly uncertain this is.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But so that is generally a range of 3 to 3½ percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s where people are, and that’s what they want to see, knowing what they know now and understanding that we need to be—we need to show resolve but also be flexible [in responding] to incoming data as we see it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If things are better, we don’t need to do that much, and if they’re not, then we either do that much or possibly even more.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But in any case, it will be very data dependent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Then you’re looking at next year, and what you’re seeing is, people see more—a bit more tightening and a range of maybe 3½ to 4 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s generally what people see as the appropriate path for getting inflation under control and starting back down and getting back down to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So 75 basis points seemed like the right thing to do at this meeting, and that’s what we did.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Steve.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Steve Liesman, CNBC.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Thank you for taking my question, Mr. Chairman.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: You have not used the phrase in a long time “monetary policy is in a good place,” which is a phrase that you used to use often.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Now that the Committee is projecting 4 percent on a—or 3.8 percent next year in terms of the funds rate, which is similar to where the market is now, the futures market of 4 percent funds rate next year, do you think that’s a level that is going to be sufficiently high enough to deal with and bring down the inflation problem?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: And just as a follow-up, could you break that apart for me?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: How much of that is restrictive, and how much of that is a normal positive rate that ought to be embedded or not, in your opinion, in the funds rate?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the question really is, how high does the rate really need to go?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And this is—the estimates on the Committee are in that range of 3½ to 4 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And how do you think about that?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, you can think about the longer-run neutral rate, you can compare it to that, and we think that’s in the mid-2s.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You can look, frankly, at broader financial conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You can look at asset prices, you can look at the effect they’re having on the economy, rates, asset prices, credit spreads—all of those things go into that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You can also look at the yield curve and ask, all along the yield curve, where is the policy rate?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So for much of the yield curve now, real rates are positive.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s not true at the short end.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At the short end of the yield curve in the early years, you don’t have real—you have negative rates still.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that really is one data point—it’s one part of financial conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think—I have to look at it this way: We move the policy rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That affects financial conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that affects the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have, of course, ways—rigorous ways to think about it, but, ultimately, it comes down to, do we think financial conditions are in a place where they’re having the desired effect on the economy?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that desired affect is, we’d like to see demand moderating.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Demand is very hot still in the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’d like to see the labor market getting better in balance between supply and demand, and that can happen [as a result of developments coming] both from supply and demand.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Right now, there’s—demand is substantially higher than available supply, though, so we feel that there’s a role for us in moderating demand.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Those are the things we can affect with our policy tools.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There are many things we can’t affect, and those would be, you know, the things—the commodity price issues that we’re having around the world due to the war in Ukraine and the fallout from that, and also just all of the supply-side things that are still pushing upward on inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s really how I think—how I think about it.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: But does 3.8 percent, 4 percent get it done?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Does it get the job done on breaking the back of inflation?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think it’s certainly in the range of plausible numbers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think we’ll know when we get there really.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, honestly, though, that would be—you would have positive real rates, I think, and inflation coming down by then.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think you’d have positive real rates across the [yield] curve.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think that the neutral rate is pretty low these days.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I would think it would, but you know what?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re going to find that out empirically.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re not going to be completely model driven about this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re going to be looking at this, keeping our eyes open, and reacting to incoming data both on financial conditions and on what’s happening in the economy.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Nick.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Nick Timiraos.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Chair Powell, you’ve said that you like your policy to work through expectations.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: And now, obviously, this decision was something quite different from how you and almost all of your colleagues had set those expectations during the intermeeting period.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: And I know you just said that what changed was really the inflation data—the inflation expectations data.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: But I’m wondering, on the inflation expectations data, was there something you saw that was unsettling enough to risk eroding the credibility of your verbal guidance by doing something so different from what you had “socialized” before?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So if you look at a broad range of inflation expectations—so you’ve got the public, you’ve got surveys of the public and of experts, and you’ve also got market based.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think if you look across that broad range of data, what you see is that expectations are still in the place, very much in the place, where short-term inflation is going to be high but comes down sharply over the next couple of years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s really where inflation expectations are.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And also, as you get away from this episode, they get back down close to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so this is really very important to us—that that remain the case.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think if you look for most measures, most of the time, that’s what you see.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If we even see a couple of indicators that bring that into question, we take that very seriously.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We do not take this for granted—we take it very seriously.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the preliminary Michigan [survey] reading—it’s a preliminary reading; it might be revised—nonetheless, it was quite eye-catching, and we noticed that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We also noticed that the index of common inflation expectations at the Board has moved up after being pretty flat for a long time, so we’re watching that, and we’re thinking, “this is something we need to take seriously.” And that is one of the factors, as I mentioned—one of the factors in our deciding to move ahead with 75 basis points today was what we saw in inflation expectations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re absolutely determined to keep them anchored at 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That was one of the reasons—the other was just the CPI reading.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: So if you saw a movement like that again, another tick-up in inflation expectations, would that put a 75 or even 100 basis point increase in play at your next meeting?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re going to—I’ll just say, we’re going to react to the incoming data and appropriately, I think.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I wouldn’t want to put a number on what that might be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The main thing is to get rates up, and then pretty soon, we’ll be in an area where we’re—I think as you get closer to the end of the year, you’re in a range where you’ve got restrictive policy, which is appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Forty-year highs in inflation—we think that policy is going to need to be restrictive, and we don’t know how restrictive.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think that’s how we’ll take it.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Neil.

speaker: NEIL IRWIN
sentence: Hi, Chair Powell.

speaker: NEIL IRWIN
sentence: Neil Irwin from Axios.

speaker: NEIL IRWIN
sentence: Thanks for taking our questions.

speaker: NEIL IRWIN
sentence: The late-breaking kind of decision to go to 75 basis points—do you worry that that will make policy guidance a less effective tool in the future?

speaker: NEIL IRWIN
sentence: And should we think of that as a kind of symmetrical reaction function if we start to get soft readings on inflation or if the labor market starts to roll over?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: To take your second question first, yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, I think we’re—again, we’re going, we’re resolved to take this on, but we’re going to be flexible in the implementation of it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sorry—and your [first] question was [about] guidance.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, again, the overall exercise is that we try to be—provide as much clarity about our policy intentions as we can, because we think that makes monetary policy work better.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s always a tradeoff, because you have to live with that guidance, and so you do it, and it helps a lot of the time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I, frankly, think this year has been a demonstration of how well it can work.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: With us having really just done very little in the way of raising interest rates, financial conditions have tightened quite significantly through the expectations channel, as we’ve made it clear what our plans are.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think that’s been a very healthy thing to be happening.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I would hope that our—it’s always going to be—any guidance that we give is always going to be subject to things working out about as we expect.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, in this particular situation, you know, we’re looking for something specific, and that is progress on inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We want to see progress.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We want to see—inflation can’t go down until it flattens out, and that’s what we’re looking to see.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And if we don’t see that, then that’s the kind of thing that will—even if we don’t see progress for a longer period, that could cause us to react.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we will.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Soon enough, we will be seeing some progress at some point.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ll react [as] appropriate to that, too.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I would like to think, though, that our guidance is still credible, but it’s always going to be conditional on what happens.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This is an unusual situation, to get, you know, some data late in, during blackout, pretty close to—very close to our meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Very unusual to [have] one that would actually change the outcome.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I’ve only seen—in my 10-years-plus here at the Fed, I’ve only seen something like that, even close to that, one or two times.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I don’t think it’s something that’ll come up a great deal.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Colby.

speaker: COLBY SMITH
sentence: Thank you so much for taking our questions.

speaker: COLBY SMITH
sentence: Colby Smith with the Financial Times.

speaker: COLBY SMITH
sentence: On the “clear and convincing” threshold for the inflation trajectory, what is the level of realized inflation that meets that criteria?

speaker: COLBY SMITH
sentence: And how is the Committee thinking about the potential tradeoff of much higher unemployment than even in what’s forecasted in the SEP if inflation is not moderating at this acceptable pace?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The second part I didn’t get.

speaker: COLBY SMITH
sentence: What’s the potential tradeoff with higher unemployment than even what’s forecasted in the SEP if inflation is not moderating at an acceptable pace?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, what we want to see is a series of declining monthly readings for inflation, and we’d like to see inflation headed down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, you know—and right now, our policy rate is well below neutral, right?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, soon enough, we’ll have our policy rate—let’s assume the world works out about like the SEP says: The policy rate will be up where we think it should be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And then the question would be: Do you slow down?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Does it make you—you’ll be making these judgments about, is it appropriate now to slow down—from 50 to 25, let’s say—or speed up?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s the kind of thinking we’ll be doing, and, again, we’re looking—ultimately, we’re not going to declare victory until we see a series of these, really see convincing evidence, compelling evidence, that inflation is coming down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s what I mean by—that’s what it would take for us to say, “Okay, we think this job is done.” Because we saw—and, frankly, we saw last year—inflation came down over the course of the summer and then turned right around and went back up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think we’re going to be careful about declaring victory.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But our—again, the implementation of our policy is going to be flexible and sensitive to incoming data.

speaker: COLBY SMITH
sentence: Are you more concerned now that to bring down inflation, it’s going to require more than just some pain at this point?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Again, I think that—I do think that our objective, and this is what’s reflected in the SEP, but our objective, really, is to bring inflation down to 2 percent while the labor market remains strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think that what’s becoming more clear is that many factors that we don’t control are going to play a very significant role in deciding whether that’s possible or not.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And there I’m thinking, of course, of commodity prices, the war in Ukraine, supply chain [developments], things like that, where we really—the monetary policy stance doesn’t affect those things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But having said that, there is a path for us to get there—it’s not getting easier; it’s getting more challenging because of these external forces—and that path is to move demand down, and you have a lot of surplus demand.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Take, for example, in the labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you have two job vacancies, essentially, for every person actively seeking a job, and that has led to a real imbalance in wage negotiating.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You could get to a place where that ratio was at a more normal level, and you wouldn’t—you would expect to see those wage pressures move back down to a level where people are still getting healthy wage increases, real wage increases, but at a level that’s consistent with 2 percent inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s a possibility.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you could say the same thing about some of the product markets where there’s just excess capacity and really where the strong demand has gone into—sorry, where they’re capacity constrained, right?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you have, effectively, what we think of as a vertical supply curve or close to it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So demand comes in, and it’s very strong, and it shows up in higher prices—not higher quantities, not more cars, because they can’t make the cars because they don’t have the semiconductors.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So in principle, that could work in reverse.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: When demand comes down, you could see—and it’s not guaranteed—but you could see prices coming down more than the typical economic relationships that you see in the textbooks would suggest, because of the unusual situation we’re in on the supply side.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So there’s a pathway there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It is not going to be easy, and there—again, it’s our objective, but, as I mentioned, it’s going to depend to some extent on factors we don’t control.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Rachel.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: Hi, Chair Powell.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: Thank you for taking our questions.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: Rachel Siegel from the Washington Post.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: So the new projections show the unemployment rate ticking up through 2024.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: Is a higher unemployment rate necessary in order to combat inflation?

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: And what is lost if the unemployment rate has to go up and people lose their jobs in order to control inflation?

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you’re right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In the SEP, we have unemployment going up to 4 point—the median is 4.1 percent—of course, [there is] a range of actual forecasts.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I would characterize that, if you were to get inflation down to, you know, on its way down to 2 percent and the unemployment rate went up to 4.1 percent, that’s still a historically low level.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We hadn’t seen—we hadn’t seen rates, unemployment rates below 4 percent until a couple years ago for—we’d seen it for, like, one year in the last 50.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the idea that—3.6 percent is historically low in the last century.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So a 4.1 percent unemployment rate with inflation well on its way to 2 percent—I think that would be—I think that would be a successful outcome.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re not looking to have a higher unemployment rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I would say that I would certainly look at that as a successful outcome.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: Would that include people losing their jobs?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re not—again, we’re not, we don’t seek to put people out of work, of course.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We never think, “Too many people are working, and fewer people need to have jobs.” But we also think that you really cannot have the kind of labor market we want without price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we have to go back and establish price stability so we can have that kind of labor market, and that’s a labor market where workers are getting wage increases—maybe the workers at the lower end of the spectrum are getting the biggest wage increases, as they were before the pandemic—where participation is high, where there’s lots of job opportunities, where it’s just a really—I mean, the labor market we had before the pandemic was—that’s what we want to get back to.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you see disparities between various groups at historic lows.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’d love to get back to that place.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, to get there—it’s not going to happen with the levels of inflation we have.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we have to restore that, and it really is in service, in the medium and longer term, of the kind of labor market we want and hope to achieve.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Matt.

speaker: MATTHEW BOESLER
sentence: Hi, Chair Powell.

speaker: MATTHEW BOESLER
sentence: Matthew Boesler with Bloomberg.

speaker: MATTHEW BOESLER
sentence: So, as you just mentioned, the Committee is now projecting a ½ percentage point rise in the unemployment rate and the SEPs over the next couple of years, and it removed a line from its policy statement about thinking that the labor market can remain strong while it tightens policy.

speaker: MATTHEW BOESLER
sentence: You just mentioned that that is still your objective, though, so I’m wondering if you could explain why that line was removed from the statement—also whether this means the FOMC is trying to induce a recession now to bring inflation down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Not trying to induce a recession now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Let’s be clear about that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re trying to achieve 2 percent inflation consistent with a strong labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s what we’re trying to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So let me talk about that sentence.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Clearly, it’s our goal to bring about 2 percent inflation while keeping the labor market strong, right?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s kind of what the SEP says.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The SEP has inflation getting down to 2, a little above 2 percent in 2024, with unemployment at 4.1 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And this is a strong labor market—this is a good labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, as I mentioned, there are pathways to do it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But those pathways have become much more challenging due to factors that are not under our control.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Again, thinking here of the fallout from the war in Ukraine, which has brought a spike in prices of energy, food, fertilizer, industrial chemicals, and also just the supply chains more broadly, which have been larger and longer lasting than anticipated.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the sentence that we deleted said that we believe that appropriate monetary policy, effectively alone, can bring about the result of 2 percent inflation with a strong labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so much of it is really not down to monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It just didn’t—the sentence isn’t—it kind of says on its face that monetary policy alone can do this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s not—that just didn’t seem appropriate, so we took the sentence out.

speaker: MATTHEW BOESLER
sentence: And given the new projections for the unemployment rate, could you talk a little bit about what accounts for such reduced confidence against, say, a month ago or three months ago that inflation will largely normalize on its own as these supply-side issues get worked out?

speaker: MATTHEW BOESLER
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, yeah, I think you’ve seen—again, we’ve been expecting progress, and we didn’t get that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We got sort of the opposite.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I also think the situation, really—since the consequences of the Ukraine war become more and more clear, what you’re seeing is the situation getting more difficult.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you look around the world—I mean, lots of countries are—lots of countries are looking at inflation of 10 percent, and it’s largely due to commodities prices.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But all over the world, you’re seeing these effects.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so—and we’re seeing them here: gas prices at all-time highs, and things like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s not something we can do something about.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that is really—and, by the way, headline inflation, headline inflation is important for expectations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: People—the public’s expectations, why would they be distinguishing between core inflation and headline inflation?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Core inflation is something we [on the Committee] think about because it is a better predictor of future inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But headline inflation is what people experience.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They don’t know what core is.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Why would they?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They have no reason to.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s—expectations are very much at risk due to high headline inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s become—the environment has become more difficult, clearly, in the last four or five months, and hence the need for the policy actions that we took today.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Hence our resolution to get rates up and, ultimately, get them to where we think they need to be in coming months.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: Thanks, Chair Powell.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: Edward Lawrence with Fox Business.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: I wanted to ask you—you talked about CPI going to 8.6 percent, that retail sales surprised the market by falling and then revisions to the previous months were down.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: Are you hearing from contacts about consumers slowing spending or changing their habits?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re, of course, watching very, very carefully for that and looking at the retail—the big store numbers and all that kind of thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so I—but I think the fair summary of what we see is, you see continuing shifts in consumption, you see some things getting—sales going down, but overall spending is very strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The consumer’s in really good shape financially.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They’re spending.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s no sign of a broader slowdown that I can see in the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: People are talking about it a lot—consumer confidence is very low.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s probably related to gas prices and also just stock prices to some extent for other people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But that’s what we’re seeing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re not seeing a broad slowdown.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We see job growth slowing, but it’s still at quite robust levels.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We see the economy slowing a bit but still growth levels—healthy growth levels.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: So then as you are raising rates in this economy, how closely are you watching consumer spending, or is there something—another indicator that you’re watching more closely?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It would be hard to watch anything much more closely than we watch consumer spending, but we watch everything.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We watch business fixed investment, which actually has softened a bit.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we watch—we’re responsible for watching everything.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Consumption is 60-some percent of the economy, two-thirds of the economy, so, naturally, we spend a lot of time on that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, again, there’s a lot going on—there are a lot of flows back and forth—but, ultimately, it does appear that the U.S. economy is in a strong position and well positioned to deal with higher interest rates.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Michael McKee.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: Michael McKee from Bloomberg Radio and Television.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: Are you targeting headline inflation now or core inflation?

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: In other words, how far would you chase oil prices if they keep going up?

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: If that’s going to be the component that drives expectations, would you risk recession for a headline rate if the core rate is holding steady or starting to go down?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the—we’re responsible for inflation in the law.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And inflation means headline inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s our ultimate goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We, of course, like all central banks do, look very, very carefully at core inflation because it is—it’s a much better predictor, and it’s much—it’s a much better predictor of where inflation is going, and it’s also more relevant to our tools.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I mentioned, the parts that don’t go into core are mostly outside the scope of our tools, so we look at that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But it’s—the current situation is particularly difficult because of what I mentioned about expectations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We can’t affect, really—I mean, the energy prices are set by global commodity prices.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And most of food—not all of it, but most food prices are pretty heavily influenced by global commodity prices, too.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Also other things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we can’t really have much of an effect.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we have to be mindful of the potential effect on inflation expectations [coming] from headline [inflation readings].

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s a very difficult situation to be in, and we—again, we can’t do much about the difference between [headline and core inflation rates due to] the elements that make up headline that are not in core.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: Could I just, as a follow-up, get a clarification on the SEP?

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: When the members gave their forecasts, when were they inserted into the record?

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: Were they revised after the CPI or Michigan numbers came out?

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: In other words, does the SEP, as we have it now, reflect the same factors that led you to go to a 75 basis point move?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The SEP is of one piece.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It reflects all of the economic readings.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It also reflects the 75 basis point increase.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This is important.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So people had that in hand when they—when their SEPs were submitted.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s—in other words, it’s not in addition to what’s in the SEP.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The SEP—everyone’s SEP reflects their thinking about this rate increase and what’s going forward.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Victoria.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: Hi, Victoria Guida from Politico.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: I wanted to ask about how you’re measuring progress, especially since you’ve now started front-loading rate hikes more.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: You’ve talked about how you want to see inflation coming down over a series of reports, and I guess I’m curious whether you think inflation data itself is a really good indicator or whether you might be concerned that it’s a lagging indicator or that it might send confusing signals given that, as you’ve talked about, there are sort of supply and demand aspects.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: And I guess my question is, do you think that inflation will tell you—inflation data will tell you when you’ve gone to where you need to go, or do you just feel like maybe it’s better to overshoot than to undershoot?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think the role that we can play—maybe the way to get at this is to say that the role that we can play is around demand, right?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ll be able to see—the areas that we can affect are those associated with excess demand, and we’ll be able to see our effect on, for example, job openings in real time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that would tell us what’s—that would tell us about wages.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Wages are not principally responsible for the inflation that we’re seeing, but, going forward, they would be very important, particularly in the service sector.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sorry, I’m not sure I’m getting to your question.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: My question is, is inflation data itself the best indicator for when you’re getting to where you need to go, or might it lead you to go too far?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s always a risk of going too far or going not far enough, and it’s going to be a very difficult judgment to make, or maybe not—maybe it’ll be really clear.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we’re—and we’re quite mindful of the dangers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I will say, the worst mistake we could make would be to fail, which—it’s not an option.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have to restore price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We really do, because everything—it’s the bedrock of the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you don’t have price stability, the economy’s really not going to work the way it’s supposed to.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It won’t work for people—their wages will be eaten up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we want to get the job done.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This inflation happened relatively recently.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t think that it’s affecting expectations in any kind of fundamental way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t think that we’re seeing a wage–price spiral.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think that the public generally sees us as very likely to be successful in getting inflation down to 2 percent, and that’s critical.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s absolutely key to the whole thing that we sustain that confidence.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s how we’re thinking about it.

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: Hi, Brian Cheung with Yahoo Finance.

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: I just want to expand, I guess, on what you just said now about the general public feeling like you can get this done.

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: You talk about consumer sentiment being down, also inflation expectations being up, recession just broadly being dinner table talk.

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: Does the general feel among American households and also businesses square with your explanation of the economy, given that the description of inflation in the statement didn’t change between May and June?

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, clearly, people don’t like inflation—a lot.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And many people are experiencing it, really, for the first time, because we haven’t had anything like this kind of inflation in 40 years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s really something people don’t like.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And they’re experiencing that, and that’s showing up in their—in surveys and in all kinds of ways.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we understand that, and we understand the hardship that people are experiencing from high inflation, and we’re determined to do what we can to get inflation back down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s really what we’re saying.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re not—I’m not—clearly, it’s an incredibly unpopular thing, and it’s very painful for people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I guess what I’m saying is, the question, the really critical question from the perspective of doing our job is making sure that the public does have confidence that we have the tools and will use them and they do work to bring inflation back down over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It will take some time, we think, to get inflation back down, but we will do that.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Chris.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: Chris Rugaber, Associated Press.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: You have talked about inflation a few times and mentioned oil prices, China lockdowns.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: But aside from rises in commodity prices such as gas prices, we’re also seeing stickier measures of inflation increasing, such as the Cleveland Fed’s median and trimmed mean CPIs.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: I mean, how persistent do you see those underlying measures of inflation, and how do you expect to—where do you see those going in the near future?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, as I mentioned, I think, in my opening statement, inflation has started—it started off in quite narrow, very directly pandemic-related areas, and it’s spread now broadly across the economy and into the services sector as well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It was really in the goods sector at the beginning.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, particularly, you’re seeing in travel now, if you’ve flown on a plane lately—planes are very full, and plane tickets are very expensive.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Some of that will be pass-through of energy prices, but it’s—so you’re experiencing services inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Shelter inflation is high.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the question—and then you see the Cleveland measure going up, and many other measures are going up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s a time when we’re not seeing progress and we want to see progress, and that’s really another part of why we did what we did today and why the SEP looks like it does.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We see it as appropriate to get the policy rate up to restrictive levels, which would be, in the thinking of the Committee, somewhere in the range of 3 to 3½ percent by year-end.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And then after that, you see what the rest of the SEP says.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I hope that’s responsive to your question.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Nancy.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: Hi, Chair Powell.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: Nancy Marshall-Genzer with Marketplace.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: Do you still think a softish landing is possible, and how would you define that at this point considering the revised projections for unemployment, GDP, inflation?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think what’s in the SEP would certainly meet that test.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you see—you’re looking at getting back down to almost a 2 percent inflation by 2024, and the unemployment rate is still as low as 4.1 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That would be—I would call that as meeting that test.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Do I still think that we can do that?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think there’s—I think there’s—I don’t want to be the handicapper here.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I just—that is our objective, and I do think it’s possible.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Like I said, though, I think that events of the last few months have raised the degree of difficulty, created great challenges.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, again, the answer to the question, can we still do it—there’s a much bigger chance now that it’ll depend on factors that we don’t control, which is, fluctuations and spikes in commodity prices could wind up taking that option out of our hands.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we just don’t know, but we’re focused on—very, very focused on getting inflation back down to 2 percent, which we think is essential for the benefit of the public and also to put us on a path back to a sustainably strong labor market like the one we had before the pandemic.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Greg.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Greg Robb from MarketWatch.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Chair Powell, I was wondering if you could talk a little bit more—economists are worried that you’re kind of hitting the economy with a sledgehammer and that now there’s even more risk of a recession than a 50–50 path of rates.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: So could you talk a little bit more about that?

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: And what evidence would get you to stop rate hikes and maybe even reverse them?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, as I mentioned, financial conditions have tightened over the last seven months, and that’s a good thing, we think.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But the federal funds rate, even after this increase, is at 1.6 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s hard to see how that is too high of a rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And even if we did another—so we’re going to get here by the end of the summer, somewhere in the 2s probably.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Still, that’s still a low rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s not a rate that is calculated to bring a recession on.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ll—by then, we’ll have seen a whole lot more data.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I mentioned a couple times, the Committee’s views are around a modestly restrictive stance, which will be in the 3 to 3½ percent range by the end of this year, but that’s conditioned on that being the appropriate thing to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If we see data going in a different direction, it’ll be reflected in our policy, as you see today.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll be watching—if things go in a direction we don’t expect, then we’re going to adapt.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I would say, this is a highly uncertain environment—extraordinarily uncertain environment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, again, we’ll be determined and resolved, but flexible.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Okay.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Evan.

speaker: EVAN RYSER
sentence: Evan Ryser, Market News International.

speaker: EVAN RYSER
sentence: Thank you, Chair Powell.

speaker: EVAN RYSER
sentence: I was wondering if the Fed has initiated a review of the conduct of monetary policy over the last two years or so, given the inflation, and will that be shared with the public?

speaker: EVAN RYSER
sentence: And then, secondly, given the illiquidity and the extraordinary volatility in financial markets, are you concerned that QT will make that worse?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sorry, what was your question on QT?

speaker: EVAN RYSER
sentence: Just given the illiquidity and extraordinary volatility in financial markets, whether QT will make things worse.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, of course, we’ve been looking very carefully and hard at why inflation picked up so much more than expected last year and why it proved so persistent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We—it’s hard to overstate the extent of interest we have in that question morning, noon, and night.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But you have to understand the context.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: For—really, the context is this: For decades before the pandemic and the reopening, you had a world where inflation was dominated by disinflationary forces such as declining population or aging demographics, let’s call it that, globalization enabled by technology, other factors, low productivity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So and that’s how all the models work is, decades and decades of data—they look at that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s a very flat Philips curve world, and the supply shocks tend to be transient, right?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we have now experienced an extraordinary series of shocks, if you think about it: the pandemic, the response, the reopening, inflation, followed by the war in Ukraine, followed by shutdowns in China—the war in Ukraine potentially having effects for years here.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re aware that a different set of forces are driving the economy—we have been, obviously, for quite a while.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But this is a different—these forces are different.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation is behaving differently, and, in our thinking, it really is a question of very strong demand.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But you couldn’t get this kind of inflation without a change on the supply side, which is there for anybody to see, which is these blockages and shortages and people dropping out of the labor force and things like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s how we’re looking at it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ve done a lot of work internally on, and thinking about, what all that means.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You don’t—the thing is, you don’t know whether those forces are—to what extent are they going to be sustained?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In other words, will we go back to a world where it looks a little more like the old world, or are we really going to be in a world where major supply shocks go on and on?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The history is, you see these waves of supply shocks, as you did in the ’70s, and then they go away, and sort of there’s a “new normal,” and things settle down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, honestly, we don’t know what that’s going to be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In the meantime, we have to find price stability in this new world and maximum employment in this new world where, clearly, inflationary forces are—you’re seeing them everywhere.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Again, if you look around the world at where inflation levels are, it’s absolutely extraordinary.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not just here.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In fact, we’re sort of in the middle of the pack, although I think we have, of course, a different kind of inflation than other people have, partly because our economy is stronger and more highly recovered.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s what we’re doing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve done a lot of introspection and work on that and—sorry, on QT, we’ve communicated really clearly to the markets about what we’re going to do there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Markets seem to be okay with it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re phasing in—Treasury [security] issuance is down quite a lot, quite a lot from where it’s been, so I have no reason to think—markets are forward looking, and they see this coming.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I have no reason to think it will lead to illiquidity and problems.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It seems to be kind of understood and accepted at this point.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: For the last question, we’ll go to Mark Hamrick.

speaker: MARK HAMRICK
sentence: Mr. Chairman, Mark Hamrick with Bankrate.

speaker: MARK HAMRICK
sentence: I wonder what your assessment is about the outlook for the housing market, given the years-long increase in home prices and now the sharp rise in mortgage rates.

speaker: MARK HAMRICK
sentence: And all that, of course, given the heightened sensitivity around the housing market given the fact that it was a trigger for the great financial crisis over a decade ago.

speaker: MARK HAMRICK
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So rates were very low—a good place to start is that rates were very, very low for quite a while because of the pandemic and the need to do everything we could to support the economy when unemployment was 14 percent and the true unemployment rate was well higher than that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that was a—rates are low, and now they’re coming back up to more normal, or above, levels.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, in the meantime, while rates were low and while demand was really high, obviously demand for housing changed from wanting to live in urban areas to some extent to living in single-family homes in the suburbs, famously.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so the demand was just suddenly much higher.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we saw prices moving up very, very strongly for the last couple of years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that changes now, and rates have moved up—we’re well aware that mortgage rates have moved up a lot—and you’re seeing a changing housing market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re watching it to see what will happen.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: How much will it really affect residential investment?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Not really sure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: How much will it affect housing prices?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Not really sure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s—I mean, obviously, we’re watching that quite carefully.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You would think over time—I mean, so there’s a tremendous amount of supply in the housing market of unfinished homes, and as those come on line—whereas the supply of finished homes, inventory of finished homes that are for sale, is incredibly low, historically low.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s still a very tight market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So prices may keep going up for a while even in a world where rates are up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s a complicated situation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We watch it very carefully.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would say if you’re a homebuyer, somebody or a young person looking to buy a home, you need a bit of a reset.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We need to get back to a place where supply and demand are back together and where inflation is down low again and mortgage rates are low again.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So this will be a process whereby we—ideally, we do our work in a way that the housing market settles in a new place and housing availability and credit availability are at appropriate levels.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So thank you very much.
